thread.title: Deadly funnel-web spider venom can reduce brain damage caused by strokes, even hours later, scientists say
thread.title_full: Deadly funnel-web spider venom can reduce brain damage caused by strokes, even hours later, scientists say

author: Chris Graham, The Telegraph
title: Deadly funnel-web spider venom can reduce brain damage caused by strokes, even hours later, scientists say
text:
Venom from the deadly Australian funnel-web spider can be used to protect the brain from devastating stroke damage, scientists have found.
Australian researchers were sequencing the DNA of the venom when they discovered a compound, which they say could protect brain cells even when injected hours after a stroke has occurred.
“We believe that we have, for the first time, found a way to minimize the effects of brain damage after a stroke,” said Professor Glenn King, from the University of Queensland’s Institute for Molecular Bioscience.
Related Zoo to Australians: Please help us catch deadly funnel-web spiders, we’re running short ‘They’re used to eating scorpions’: Angelina Jolie and her kids eat insects—should you? The scientists at the University of Queensland and Monash University made the discovery when they were examining venom extracted from spiders found in Orchid beach, 402 km north of Brisbane.
While the venom from these spiders can kill a human within 15 minutes, the protein they discovered, Hi1, is not only harmless, but could also be a game-changer in treating strokes.
A dose of the protein two hours after the stroke cut down the brain damage in rats by 80 per cent, Professor King wrote in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences.
Even when it was given eight hours after the attack, it reduced damage to the brain by about 65 per cent.
